title: Do you try to live a deontology life? - Quora

response.answer_text: You mean, do I try to live by the ethical principles of some deontological (duty-based) approach such as Kant’s categorial imperative? I would say that is not my approach, no, although I have long thought that deontological and consequentialist systems ultimately dove-tail into some common positions. In either case, he point is that you don’t just think of yourself. In my case, I would say the closest principle for me might be “rule based, unselfish utilitarianism.” That idea translates into the following, but applies the idea it should be applied to general rules, not just to individual circumstances: The greatest happiness for the greatest number. That may be close to where I am. But ultimately, I think there is a principle even closer to where I am, and more foundational for both consequentialist and deontological ethics alike. Ready? Here it is: Other minds are real. Therefore I should want for others as much happiness as I want for myself. Is this out of a sense of moral duty? If so, maybe you could call it “deontological.” But I just think of as “morally aware” more than a “duty.” It’s ultimately the only fully logical position, I believe, although it dovetails with such emotions as empathy. Because selfishness is ultimately not logical. I am not the only human alive, any more than I am standing at the center of the universe. Therefore, if I wish for my own happiness more than for any others, am I not being unreasonable? Another person’s pain or pleasure is as real as my own. To acknowledge that is to be a morally aware human being.

No, instead I try to live a healthy life. Duty and obligation and the resultant rules are constraints; they are often one sided and self limiting. I believe in balance. To do only out of duty is unkind, better to do because you chose to do. If you are giving it is important also to receive in some way, even it is just to see and receive a smile. To keep giving without receiving is out of balance. There are no clear cut rules for life yet I sense there is a simple way to be which is hard to find and practice. Deontology : study of the nature of duty and obligation.

No. Morality seems a lot like law in that you need a specific case, procedures and guidelines governing what can be considered and how to reach a conclusion about what implicit obligations exist in any given situation. For example, there are exceptions to virtually every moral tenet—theft, murder, lying, etc. Any attempt to preemptively deduce the perfect ethic seems sophistic at best to me—although it might be a thought provoking exercise. I try to consider most of the consequences of actions I’m considering, and I try to find efficient heuristics for engineering a fair economy. But no, I don’t seek to live by some reckoned archetype of righteousness.
